node.title: Join our January Blanket Drive on GoFundMe!

title.en-US: January Blanket Drive poster, embedded image

description.en-US: Image poster of BTO's January Blanket Drive on GoFundMe, featuring a drawing of an individual making a donation.

content.value: With the frigid temperatures and heavy snowfall of the Canadian winter upon us, Blankets for T.O. is organizing a January Blanket Drive to help keep the homeless warm!
Join the cause by making a donation on our GoFundMe page here
Share the link with your friends, family, classmates and colleagues!
For each $2 donated in this Blanket Drive, you will be able to provide a warm thermal blanket for a homeless individual.
Watch our January Blanket Drive video
, which summarizes the goals of Blankets for T.O. and our blanket drive.
To start off this drive, we aimed for a goal of $500
which is enough for 250 blankets!
But we received such overwhelming support and donations within the first 24 hours!
We are now raising our goal $750!

All proceeds of the fundraiser will go directly towards buying thermal blankets for the homeless population in the Greater Toronto Area. These high-quality thermal blankets will provide the homeless with a warm, portable, waterproof and highly visible covering for the winter.
Follow us on our social media to learn more about our organization! Thanks for your support!

childMarkdownRemark.html: Blankets for T.O. is organizing a January Blanket Drive on GoFundMe, where every $2 donated will give a thermal blanket to someone in need.

imagePreview.description: Image of person making donation to individual, in spirit of BTO's January Blanket Drive.

node.title: Laurier HCI wins the 2022 BTO Tote Bag Competition

description.en-US: Screen capture from the 2022 Blankets for T.O. Tote Bag Competition virtual event

content.value: Groups from all across Canada attended Blankets for T.O.’s first Tote Bag Competition, held virtually on December 27th over Zoom.

In the Tote Bag Competition, participating groups are asked to design a tote bag which would serve as a care package donatable to a homeless individual. They were then tasked with presenting their tote bag in a short video, which could be shared on social media, and during the virtual event on December 27th.

The goal of the Tote Bag Competition was to spread awareness about the necessities and issues that homeless individuals face. To make a great tote bag, we encouraged groups to reach out to their local homeless shelters and do their own independent research into what supplies would be most appreciated by the homeless community. By opening the competition to groups from various universities and provinces, we aimed to bring attention to homelessness issues to a much wider audience.

We received submissions from a diverse range of student associations and organizations located at universities from across Canada, including the University of Toronto, University of Ottawa, York University, University of Western Ontario and Wilfrid Laurier University. Each group made wonderful videos introducing their tote bag:

description.en-US: Photo collage of submissions to the 2022 Blankets for T.O. Tote Bag Competition

content.value: In the run-up to the virtual event, Blankets for T.O. even received press coverage in the Toronto Star! Readers would have seen the article written by our very own Mei Ling Chow (BTO Director of Finance) and Zaynab Azeem (BTO First Year Representative). The article is available online
here
if you want a light three minute read. We also used the hashtag #carepackagecascade to promote the event on social media.

Submissions were scored following four categories: Item Quality, Creativity, Usefulness and Presentation. We valued submissions that showed effort in selecting high quality items that would be practical for homeless individuals. Judges also valued submissions showing creative and innovative ideas on how care packages can address daily needs and key necessities.
With the tote bags and videos scored by the judges at Blankets for T.O., winners of the competition were announced at the end of the virtual event after presentations from every participant.
Congratulations to
Laurier Homeless Care Initiative (LHCI)
for winning the competition with their high quality, expansive and well thought-out care package!

For their win, they will receive a $500 prize that will go towards an initiative of their choosing. Additionally, we will be working with Laurier HCI to incorporate their items into new care packages for distribution in 2022. Second place, as well as its $250 prize, was secured by
The Olive Mission,
for their care package which was made with direct consultation to local groups. Finally, third place was secured by
Scar Robo
for their skillful use of poetry in their video to present a well-rounded care package. Their organization will be given a $100 prize towards an initiative of their choice.

Thank you to all the participants of the Tote Bag Competition and all the attendees of the virtual event. It wouldn’t have been such a great success if these groups did not take time out of their busy schedules to put together a submission for the event. Also, thank you to everyone that shared, commented and liked the event on social media, as you supported your clubs through the Tote Bag Competition. This event is an important stepping stone for Blankets for T.O. in addressing the homelessness crisis in the GTA, and we hope to organize collaborations with other student groups in the future!

childMarkdownRemark.html: In the first ever Tote Bag Competition hosted by Blankets for T.O., LHCI wins the grand prize for their tote bag design for the homeless.

imagePreview.description: Preview image for the Blankets for T.O. tote bag competition

content.value: During the evening of Friday October 29th 2021, Blankets for T.O. hosted a paint night for our members and students in the UTSC community. The event was held in a campus lecture hall in the Instructional Centre and we decorated the whole place with ghosts and ghouls for the occasion.

For only a $5 admission ticket, attendees were provided with a wide selection of paints, blank canvases, and brushes that they could use to show off both their breathtaking imagination and artistry. To tie in some nostalgia, we also organized a viewing of Coraline, a creepy 2008 animated classic movie, to fuel the creative juices and dive headfirst into the spooky Halloween spirit. There was an opportunity to also buy some high-quality BTO styled masks and stickers!

(Pictured below: BTO Secretary Nivedita Upadhyay (left) and VP Internal Jessika Krzyzewski (right) pose for a photo at the mask and sticker stand. A mysterious individual with a Ghost face mask looms between them. Scary!)

description.en-US: Image of BTO executives at Halloween paint night 2021

content.value: The event was filled with high energy and fun, with attendees painting all sorts of scary and Halloween-themed images.
We gave attendees the chance to compete for a grand prize given for the best painting of the night
. Decided by our followers on Instagram (
by the way, why don't you follow us over at
@blanketsforto
?), one member was rewarded the prize for their amazing Coraline-inspired painting. Congrats!
The night concluded with attendees getting a chance to model with their masterpieces (one included below!), and all were given the chance to take home a cool polaroid to remember the evening.

description.en-US: Painting of pumpkins drawn at the Blankets for T.O. Halloween Paint Night 2021

content.value: If you missed out on our spooky Halloween paint night,
don’t worry!

Blankets for T.O. has tons of future events planned for our members and UTSC students - be sure to follow us on social media, and subscribe to our email list, to keep up to date with everything we’re up to!
See our socials and contact links here

childMarkdownRemark.html: In the afternoon of Friday October 29th 2021, Blankets for T.O. hosted a paint night for our members and students in the UTSC community.

imagePreview.description: Small preview image of Halloween paint night

content.value: To get into the myths of homelessness, we first need to define what homelessness is. According to the Library of Parliament, homeless is divided into three broad terms:
Absolute homelessness: This is a narrow term that includes people who live on the streets or in emergency shelters.

Hidden or concealed homelessness: This term falls in the middle of the continuum and includes people living without a place of their own. This could include a car, with family or a long-term institution.

Relative homelessness: This falls on the other end of the continuum and is a broad category covering those who live in a house but live in substandard shelters, or may be at risk of losing their house.
To fully comprehend the umbrella term that is
homelessness
, it is best to think of it as a pyramid in which homelessness is the tip of the iceberg.
According to various organizations, for every homeless person visible on the street, there are four whose homelessness is concealed.
Around 250,000-300,000 Canadians suffer from homelessness every year, and almost 25,000-30,000 bear the consequences of homelessness on any given night.
Since a substantial part of our community is facing this problem, it is important we address some myths and make it our job to educate ourselves more on the issue.
The most prominent stereotype imposed on the homeless is that the majority of them abuse drugs and alcohol
. This, as a matter of fact, is entirely false as statistics show only about 20-40% of the homeless community has a substance abuse history/problem.
Oftentimes, substance abuse is more so a coping mechanism or response to homelessness as they are exposed to more dealers and users of the substance

. Another stereotype imposed on homeless people is them being criminals.  This mainly happens because most of the homeless’ daily activities are criminalized such as getting arrested for minor offences like trespassing, littering and loitering. The next big claim is that the homeless people chose this life because of their bad choices. We have all made mistakes at some point in our lives; however, the fall to homelessness comes more as a direct result of one losing their job, being a victim to an illness, experiencing an unfortunate accident, or falling into debt.
We have all heard this one: “They just need to get a job”.

A good portion of homeless people are working, but they simply cannot afford to pay rent. Moreover, most of the job listings require a stable housing, address and proper clothing, which makes getting a job much harder for the homeless. Another stereotype is that the homeless choose to live in unsanitary conditions . When people are conditioned to living outside, they are automatically in a place where there is no daily disposal for bodily functions, no set place to dispose of trash, nor containers to store food.  The last myth we will be discussing is the notion that there are plenty of services and support for the homeless. While this stands true, it only works in the short-term, there are individuals seeking long-term solutions to get out of the cycle of homelessness. It is integral we shed light on the need for more affordable housing and the need to confront the rising criminalization of homelessness which inhibits this community from receiving the permanent shelter that they need.

childMarkdownRemark.html: We discuss some common stereotypes revolving around the homeless community and debunk some major myths in the community.

description.en-US: Front photo of Supreme Court of Canada building in Ottawa

content.value: Earlier this year, Quebec Premier François Legault said he expected people living on the street to abide by the province's curfew. The imposed four-week overnight curfew saw Quebecers needing to stay home between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m., with few exceptions. This included those who were experiencing homelessness, as Legault argued because of the cold, they should seek indoor shelter, and that “there is enough room available." Local advocates in the community, such as Nakuset, quickly spoke up in response to Legault’s comments, calling them “tone-deaf” for expecting homeless individuals to follow curfew.

Not only do individuals experiencing homelessness have to endure the very condition of homelessness, but also the discriminatory nature of the law. Nakuset’s fears were that police would fine homeless people, because they would be breaking the curfew. Geneviève Guilbault, Quebec's public security minister, stated the police would act with “appreciation” and “judgment” before ticketing a homeless person (the main goal ultimately to help find them a place). This example showcases the way in which the homeless population in Canada experiences discrimination, inadequate protective legislation, and lack of consideration when it comes to the law.

While services like shelters and food programs tend to the immediate needs of individuals experiencing homelessness, it fails to prevent and transfer individuals out of this situation. Homeless individuals mainly spend time in public areas since they do not have access to a private space; however, some distinguished city officials view this as a “threat” to urban safety, and hence need the involvement of law enforcement officials. Gaetz (2013) stated, with regards to the “criminalization of homelessness”:

The key here is that people who occupy public spaces (because they lack private ones) and whose poverty is highly visible are subject to extra attention by the criminal justice system not so much for what they do, but for
who
they are and
where
they are (p. 338).

Moreover, this can lead to the creation of new laws that indirectly target the homeless population by prohibiting them sleeping in public areas, sitting on sidewalks, and/or panhandling to ask for money. Increased enforcement of existing laws can also arise to maintain health and safety standards, but negatively impact the homeless. Attention must be paid to political and social justice issues as the execution of these regulatory practices are evidently influenced by underlying biases and affect the vulnerable members of our society.

Because of the harsh nature of such policing activities, it is not uncommon for homeless individuals to face incarceration even if they commit minor offences. Since they do not have a permanent address, they will likely be denied bail and thus remain in custody. Upon release, they usually either stay with family or friends temporarily, or go to a shelter, but inevitably, they do not have money or clean attire, leading some to quickly re-offend for the sole reason of trying to survive. These correctional facilities then become a provider of basic relief services for them as opposed to a place of restraint to crime.
What can be done instead?

To prevent these setbacks, policies should be set in place to provide homeless individuals access to suitable housing before they are released from custody. Discharge planning services should also be offered before and following their leave from correctional facilities to ensure that they can securely relocate. Additionally, upon their departure, they should be provided with clean clothes, an up-to-date list of community resources, and fares for public transport for an undisturbed transition back into society.
Key Takeaway

Now that you have reached the end of this article, we hope that you were able to gain a new perspective on how the law, while seeming to exist for everyone’s protection, often does not work in favour of our homeless population. These individuals do not choose to remain homeless, but instead are oppressed by predisposed societal regulations. It is crucial that we as a community come together to support these vulnerable persons and dismantle existing prejudices for the betterment of society.
References
Gaetz, Stephen.
Youth Homelessness in Canada: Implications for Policy and Practice
. Canadian Homelessness Research Network, 2013.
Hulchanski, John David.
Finding Home: Policy Options for Addressing Homelessness in Canada
. Cities Centre, 2009.
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/legault-homeless-curfew-covid-1.5864560

childMarkdownRemark.html: A look into how underlying biases in the Canadian Justice System indirectly target our homeless population.

node.title: Blankets for T.O. General Meeting Fall 2021

content.value: Blankets for T.O. held its annual general meeting on
Thursday September 16th, 2021

from 7pm to 8pm over Zoom! We introduced ourselves to the UTSC student community and laid out our plans for the 2021-2022 school year. It was amazing to see the turnout and it was especially encouraging to see how many first year students were interested in our cause!
Need a refresher on what we discussed? Or did you miss it? Don’t worry, read below for a short summary!
Who is Blankets for T.O.?

Founded in 2019, Blankets for T.O. is a non-profit organization at UTSC providing support and resources to those in need of housing around the Greater Toronto Area. We advocate for ending the stigma associated with homelessness and breaking down barriers preventing their reintegration into society, by working with shelters, Members of Parliament, professors, and local organizations.
How can I get involved with Blankets for T.O.?

Joining the Blankets for T.O. cause gives everyone a chance to give back to and be part of the community to make a difference. It is also an opportunity to develop your skills, make new friendships, and build your confidence.
Start with viewing and following us on social media (
links here

)! Consider signing up for our club membership for 2021-2022, since members are offered exclusive access to discounts from our sponsors, raffles and giveaways. We will also be sharing opportunities to volunteer with us during the 2021-2022 school year.
This year we plan on offering volunteer opportunities and co-curricular record recognition to our members!
More information will be coming out later this semester.
We also accepted applications for two executive positions: First Year Representative and Graphic Designer.
Applications closed on September 20th. Thanks to all those applied! We are currently going over applications and we will introduce our new executive members soon.
Giveaway and Scavenger Hunt
We held a raffle draw for an Amazon gift card for attendees of our general meeting!
Participants earned tickets for their participation in the meeting and interactions over social media.
Congratulations to Ming Ming Gong for winning the draw!
Try our
Scavenger Hunt activity

made by our Vice President of Technology, William Huang, where you can show off your knowledge of Blankets for T.O. and of our site! Although you will no longer receive raffle tickets for participating, see how much you know about us!
From our executive team: thank you!

Thank you so much to those who came out to our meeting! We were excited to see so many motivated students, especially first year students, in attendance. Many were eager to know how they could make donations themselves and how they could get involved with our events going forward.
Have any questions for us? See
here
for links to contact us over social media or email.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Read a summary of our Annual General Meeting on September 16th, where we introduced Blankets for T.O. to the UTSC community.

node.title: Election 2021: How each party approached homelessness this year

description.en-US: Image of Canada's Parliament. Photo by Benoit Debaix on Unsplash.

content.value: How is each federal party approaching homelessness and housing issues in Canada? Here, we present a list of important initiatives relevant to these issues, sourced from party campaign materials. Blankets for T.O. has also tried to reach out to the federal candidates in the riding of Scarborough-Rouge Park in order to give a glimpse at what policies each party is advocating for.
Liberal Party of Canada
According to party policy, the Liberals plan to:

Appoint a new Federal Housing Advocate within the first 100-days of a new mandate to ensure the federal government's work toward eliminating chronic homelessness, as well as other housing commitments, are fulfilled
Attempting to create affordable housing for vulnerable people like women and children fleeing violence, persons with disabilities, and youth
Work with Indigenous partners to create a National Indigenous Housing Centre with Indigenous people overseeing federal Indigenous housing programs once fully realized
Since 2015, the Liberal Party says that it has:
Created Canada’s National Housing Strategy → 10 year plan to invest over $72 billion to build supply, making housing affordable, and address chronic homelessness
Introduced legislation recognizing the right of Canadians to access adequate housing
Tripled the federal government's investment in homelessness prevention and reduction
Launched the Rapid Housing Initiative, investing $2.5 billion to create at least 9,200 new units of affordable housing across Canada
Conservative Party of Canada
According to party policy, the CPC plan to:
Re-implement the Housing First approach, which has been watered down by the current federal government, to aid in the fight against Canada’s addictions crisis

‘Housing First’ is a recovery-oriented approach that is based on rapidly moving homelessness individuals into independent and permanent housing and then providing additional supports and services as needed
Implement a strategy to combat homelessness among veterans and explore the potential for using surplus military housing to provide housing for homeless veterans
Invest $325 million over the next three years to create 1,000 residential drug treatment beds and build 50 recovery community centres across the country
New Democratic Party
The NDP plan to:
Fully implement the right to housing and work toward the goal of ending homelessness in Canada within a decade
Support the creation of more social housing and other affordable options
Work with partners in community services and the veterans community to end veteran homelessness for good

Work with the provinces and municipalities to fast-track the purchase, lease and conversion of hotels and motels for emergency housing relief until more permanent, community-based solutions are available
People’s Party of Canada
The PPC plan to:

Stop funding social housing, which they say unfairly competes with private developers and has historically been a financial, social and urban planning disaster in every city where it’s become widespread
Reduce dependency on government handouts
Modify the Bank of Canada’s inflation target, from 2% to 0% to cool down inflation in all sectors, including housing
Substantially reduce immigration quotas, from ~400k planned by the Liberals, down to 100k-150k per year to help reduce demand for housing
References
https://thevarsity.ca/2021/09/12/federal-election-2021-candidate-profiles-for-scarborough-rouge-park/
https://liberal.ca/wp-content/uploads/sites/292/2021/09/Platform-Forward-For-Everyone.pdf
https://cpcassets.conservative.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/08200659/e4cd8c0115c3ea0.pdf
https://xfer.ndp.ca/2021/Commitments/Ready%20for%20Better%20-%20NDP%202021%20commitments.pdf
https://www.peoplespartyofcanada.ca/housing

childMarkdownRemark.html: Blankets for T.O. summarizes each party's approach to homelessness and housing, based on candidates in Scarborough-Rouge Park.

node.title: Homelessness among Canada's Indigenous peoples: an issue fueled by injustices

description.en-US: Image of Canada's Parliament. Photo by Benoit Debaix on Unsplash.

content.value: “The topic of Aboriginal homelessness - and poverty in general - is inherently political and this should be acknowledged as an integral part of any productive discussion” (
Aboriginal homelessness in Canada: a literature review

In 2008, former Prime Minister of Canada Stephen Harper made an apology on behalf of the Canadian government to the Indigenous peoples of Canada regarding their treatment in Residential schools. Over a decade prior, the last Residential school - a government funded institution run by the Catholic Church to “assimilate” the Indigenous populations of Canada founded after Confederation - had closed. Indigenous children were kidnapped from their families and sent thousands of miles away to these “schools'', in which they were stripped of their native language, culture, and Indigenous identity.

Harper’s issued apology was viewed as the first step towards finding reconciliation and healing for the victims who experienced sexual and physical abuse within these institutions; however, little action has been taken with regards to the continued marginalization experienced by the Indigenous peoples of Canada. This is where the discussion of Indigenous homelessness takes place, as Indigenous peoples face discrimination and have a significantly different experience when it comes to homelessness.
Residential schools contributed to homelessness today

Firstly, Indigenous homelessness is better described and understood through Indigenous worldviews. These worldviews include individuals, families and communities isolated from their relationships to land, water, place, kin, each other, animals, cultures, languages and identities. Within the Canadian context, homelessness is confined to four categories -
Unsheltered, Emergency Sheltered, Provisionally Accommodated
and
At Risk of Homelessness.

While these four categories relate to the current circumstances of limited affordable housing and other socioeconomic issues, Indigenous homelessness takes into account the historical context of racism and displacement faced by First Nations, Métis and Inuit Peoples from their traditional governance and lands. Thus, the Canadian government’s establishment and funding of Residential schools contributed heavily to Indigenous homelessness, as the active effort to unravel their culture, society and traditions (cultural genocide) has left many First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Peoples within a state of generational trauma.
What are Indigenous viewpoints on homelessness?

As articulated by Indigenous Peoples, there are twelve dimensions of Indigenous homelessness. These dimensions are tied to colonization, and how Indigenous minds, bodies, and lands have been colonized. They include
overcrowding
homelessness,
historic displacement
homelessness,
mental disruption
and
imbalance
homelessness,
escaping or evading
harm homelessness, and
climate refuge
homelessness. Some of these dimensions sound familiar and are also experienced by Canadians, but these have all been placed into the Indigenous perspective.
Understanding the intersectionality of Indigenous homelessness is a vital step towards addressing the ways in which homelessness impacts Indigenous Peoples

. For example, overcrowding within the Indigenous context highlights the lack of affordable housing within Indigenous communities, as Indigenous households exceed the number of persons per dwelling compared to the average Canadian household in urban and rural communities. This overcrowding results in unsafe and unhealthy living conditions, where individuals feel the need to turn to homelessness.
What is also important to address is the narrative of Indigenous Peoples always being portrayed as traumatized, poor and sickly individuals

. There is little coverage of Indigenous women who have overcome circumstances such as poverty, homelessness, addiction or trauma. As well, within academic literature, there is a homogenization that takes place when it comes to describing and categorizing Canadian Indigenous populations.
Not every Indigenous population, group, or community experiences homelessness the same way

. There is significant diversity that takes place, and addressing that while there may be similarities, it is important to distinguish the fact every Indigenous population is different and has unique experiences.
Ongoing injustices and inequalities continue to contribute to homelessness

Overall, it is clear that the apology made by Harper on behalf of Canada has remained what it stood as thirteen years ago - simply words. And since Harper, empty promises have been made to combat issues that impact Indigenous communities, such as the high number of missing and murdered Indigenous women, insane Northern food prices, and lack of clean water. The severe lack of care for Canada’s Indigenous Peoples is a key contributor to ongoing homelessness in their communities. This also highlights the ways in which intersectionality plays a significant part in someone’s life. Social and societal issues impact people in different ways, and taking into consideration these multiple perspectives and experiences faced by a racially marginalized population aids society when discussing ways in which to help these unique communities.
References
Patrick, C. (2014).
Aboriginal homelessness in Canada: a literature review
. Canadian Homelessness Research Network Press.
Thistle, Jesse A.
Definition of Indigenous Homelessness in Canada
. Canadian Observatory on Homelessness, 2017.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessika Krzyzewski explores the historical impacts of policy, including residential schools, on homelessness among Canada's Indigenous.

imagePreview.description: Photo of Parliament by Benoit Depaix on Unsplash

content.value: How did we contribute?

On July 3, 2021, the Blankets for T.O. team helped out at Member of Parliament Shaun Chen’s Canada Day event, where 1,000 giveaway bags were distributed to local residents. Days prior to the event, we helped to package the giveaway bags which included items like medical face masks, disinfecting wipes, a t-shirt, a bottle of hand sanitizer, a toy, various food items, and Canada Day merchandise. Our team assisted in transporting the bags to the site at the parking lot of Woodside Square and set up the area for the drive-thru event. The Blankets for T.O. team had lots of fun helping to direct traffic and handing out the giveaway bags to attendees!

title.en-US: Blankets for T.O. at MP Shaun Chen's Canada Day Weekend Giveaway Drive-Thru

description.en-US: Members of the Blankets for T.O. team with MP Shaun Chen, during his Canada Day Weekend Giveaway Drive-Thru on July 3rd, 2021.

content.value: Despite the long hours of preparation and being outside in the hot weather, it was undoubtedly a humbling experience for us and all the other helpers. We were able to celebrate Canada Day together and connect with the community while supporting them during these tough times.

This event was my first volunteer experience which involved such a large number of people. Putting a smile on everyone’s face was extremely worthwhile and helped to reinforce my sense of purpose. I can certainly say that this event has stimulated my enthusiasm to participate in future community-driven initiatives, no matter how big or small my contribution may be.
Mei Ling, Director of Finance at Blankets for T.O.

At Blankets for T.O., we are always grateful for opportunities to help out the community in any way that we can. A big thank you to MP Shaun Chen and his team for organizing this great event and to everyone who showed up!

childMarkdownRemark.html: Members of the Blankets for T.O. team helped with MP Shaun Chen's giveaway event to celebrate Canada Day 2021!

imagePreview.description: Members of the Blankets for T.O. team with MP Shaun Chen, during his Canada Day Weekend Giveaway Drive-Thru on July 3rd, 2021.

node.title: Care Packages complete, MP honours Blankets for T.O.

content.value: As this school year comes to a close, Blankets for T.O. organized the Care Package Event which aimed to donate items to shelters around Scarborough. As we prepared our donations, we also received a visit from local Member of Parliament Shaun Chen, who honoured us with a certificate!
What is the Care Package Event?

The goal of the Care Package Event was to collect numerous items which are often in short supply in homeless shelters and gather them into personalized packages for donation. With the help of the shelter at Warden Woods Community Centre, we chose items that are important for safety during the pandemic, like hand sanitizer and masks, as well as personal hygiene items which are often in high demand. Additionally, our Blankets for T.O. members gave excellent ideas for items to include!

Our care packages were meticulously made by our Blankets for T.O. executive team on March 26th, 2021 while on the University of Toronto Scarborough campus. These care packages were subsequently donated to two shelters around Scarborough, including the respite site at the Warden Woods Community Centre.

title.en-US: Executives pack during the care package event, March 2020

description.en-US: Blankets for T.O. executives are seen packing the care packages for Blanket's for T.O.'s care package event on March 26th, 2021. Photo taken on the University of Toronto Scarborough campus.

content.value: What is in each care package?
Each care package is a drawstring bag containing items that are often tough to come by for residents of shelters. Each bag contains:
thermal blanket
hand sanitizer
face masks
headphones
toothbrush + toothpaste
rain poncho
adhesive bandages
pen
granola bars

personalized note: our kind members submitted to us messages of positivity and encouragement, which we added in as notes that care package recipients will read. We hope that these words can brighten up their days!

a vaccination leaflet: a short and sweet information card that tackles some of the common origins of vaccine hesitancy within the homeless community. We aim to help people in need to better understand vaccines and address their concerns to ultimately promote higher vaccination rates!
In total,
we packaged 800 items
! This is about
80 care packages in total
Blankets for T.O. receives a visit from a local MP

Shaun Chen, the Member of Parliament for Scarborough North, came by to the University of Toronto Scarborough to talk to us about our event! We talked about homelessness in Scarborough and explained our plans for events and fundraising.

title.en-US: Co-presidents with Shaun Chen during Care Package Event March 2021

description.en-US: Blankets for T.O. co-presidents stand with MP Shaun Chen (Scarborough North) at the front of the University of Toronto Scarborough Student Centre holding donation bags made for the Care Package Event on March 26th, 2021.

content.value: Blankets for T.O. is also honoured to have received a certificate from Shaun Chen's office. The certificate recognizes organization's efforts "
to address homelessness by distributing essential items to those in need in the Greater Toronto Area
". Our "
generosity and acts of care during the COVID-19 pandemic are greatly valued and will significantly impact our community
Below are photos of our co-founders accepting this special and customized certificate:

title.en-US: MP Shaun Chen gives certificate to cofounders

description.en-US: Pictures of Blankets for T.O. co-founders accepting a certificate from Member of Parliament Shaun Chen during the Care Package Event on March 26th, 2021.

content.value: The Care Package Event comes to a close

The Blankets for T.O. care package event was a complete success! We would like to thank the executive team that organized such a daunting event. Thanks to our members for giving us their input about items to donate and offering us help in obtaining them.

Thank you MP Shaun Chen for making our Care Package Event much more special! Blankets for T.O. is always open to working with local community leaders, as well as with politicians, regardless of their affiliation!
Want to work with us? Send us a message
here

childMarkdownRemark.html: During the Blankets for T.O. Care Package Event we donated packages of essential items to local shelters and were honoured by a local MP.

imagePreview.description: Poster image for the Blankets for T.O. Care Package Event, during March 2021.

content.value: We collaborate with
Water.org
to provide students with opportunities to socialize with friends and win prizes in games and raffles, while becoming better informed about homelessness in Toronto and water scarcity around the world.

childMarkdownRemark.html: We collaborate with Water.org to better inform students about homelessness in Toronto and water scarcity around the world.

imagePreview.description: Blankets for TO Logo with snow background

content.value: November 2020 at BTO was highlighted by two initiatives we were able to complete amid the difficult circumstances posed by the COVID-19 Pandemic.
Donation to a Homeless Shelter

We completed a food distribution initiative this month to distribute 10 packs of 60 donuts to the homeless across Toronto. One of our stops was to a homeless shelter at the Warden Woods Community Centre.
Our Day at the Hot Dog Stand
To help out local small businesses during the hardships of the COVID-19 pandemic, we decided to help promote an example of one through our social media! Blankets for T. O. worked with the owner of
Nasir's Gourmet Hot Dog Stand
, a food stand located right at the front of the UTSC campus.

Now that nearly all university classes have went online, his business has been struggling immensely with the lack of foot traffic. Blankets for T.O spent the day to take a photo shoot and to help promote his business. A video showcasing his business and his awesome food was uploaded to our
TikTok, immediately getting traffic and likes! View the video
here
Be sure to check his food out when you get the chance to. Let's show our support to local families and small businesses!

childMarkdownRemark.html: In November 2020, Blankets for T.O. donated donuts to a local shelter and also promoted a local small business on campus.

imagePreview.description: A split image of our events in November 2020; Nasir's Hot Dog Stand promotion and our donut distribution initiative.

content.value: Blankets for T.O. hosted two events for October 2020!
We started off the Fall semester by organizing an open giveaway for a $20 Amazon gift card and Blankets for T.O. membership.

In the spirit of Halloween, we hosted a pumpkin carving competition open to all UTSC students! It was also a good time to destress from midterm exams, since students were able to socialize and have a good time while competing to carve the best jack-o'-lantern they could. The pumpkins carved were awesome! Thanks to all those who participated!

childMarkdownRemark.html: In October, Blankets for T.O. hosted a pumpkin carving contest for UTSC students and giveaway.

content.value: Given the ever-present circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic, the meet and greet for the start of the Fall 2020 term at UTSC moved online to Zoom. We introduced Blankets for T.O. and shared our vision to UTSC students and prospective members.
It was also at this time that we further extended our social media presence. You can now reach us over Facebook, Instagram, and Tiktok! All our links can be reached via our
Contact page

childMarkdownRemark.html: Blankets for T.O. held a meet and greet over Zoom at the start of the Fall term to introduce ourselves to the community!

imagePreview.description: Blankets for TO Logo with snow background

content.value: To mark Valentine's Day, BTO members organized a blanket distribution!

We embarked on a 5 kilometre journey around downtown Toronto and distributed thermal blankets to the homeless. The weather was cold, but we remained warm and friendly! Here are pictures we took of just some of the donations we were able to make.
Money earned through membership fees, donations, and events held by Blankets for T.O. will go towards purchasing blankets for future blanket distributions like this one!

childMarkdownRemark.html: Read about how Blankets for T.O. members distributed blankets in downtown Toronto on a chilly Valentine's Day.

content.value: Blankets for T.O. successfully hosted a meet and greet at the University of Toronto Scarborough for students to introduce our organization to the community. First of all, thank you to all those students that were able to take the time to come! It was amazing to see and meet all of you. The agenda of the session was to inform students about how they could contribute to Blankets for T.O., including how they could become a member, apply for executive positions, donate to the cause, and become a volunteer at future events.
It also wouldn't be a Blankets for T.O. meeting if we did not show off our blankets! In case you missed it, here it was:
Blankets for T.O. is looking forward to working with the community! For those who were not able to attend, do not worry! We will have plenty of updates through our
social media
and
website

childMarkdownRemark.html: Blankets for T.O. hosted a meet and greet at the University of Toronto Scarborough to introduce our organization to the student community.
